content.text: Define _velocity_
Use data from Fig. 1.1 to calculate \(k\)
Use your answer in **(b)(i)** and data from Fig. 1.1 to determine the value of \(k\), with its absolute uncertainty, to an appropriate number of significant figures
The speed \(\nu\) of a sound wave through a gas of pressure \(P\) and density \(\rho\) is given by the equation
where \(k\) is a constant that has no units
An experiment is performed to determine the value of \(k\). The data from the experiment are shown in Fig. 1.1
Define _linear momentum_
determine the time interval over which the blocks are in contact with each other
time interval =   .........  \(ms\)
describe, without calculation, the magnitude of the acceleration of block Y from:
1. time \(t = 80 \text{ms}\) to \(t = 100 \text{ms}\)
2. time \(t = 100 \text{ms}\) to \(t = 120 \text{ms}\)
Use Fig. 2.2 to:
Use Fig. 2.2 to determine the magnitude of the force exerted by block X on block Y
On Fig. 2.2, sketch the variation of the momentum of block X with time \(t\) from \(t = 0\) to \(t = 160 \text{ms}\)
A block X slides along a horizontal frictionless surface towards a stationary block Y, as illustrated in Fig. 2.1

There are no resistive forces acting on block X as it moves towards block Y. At time \(t = 0\), block X has momentum \(0.40 \text{kg} \text{m} \text{s}^{-1}\). A short time later, the blocks collide and then separate
The variation with time \(t\) of the momentum of block Y is shown in Fig. 2.2
use Fig. 3.1 to show that the increase in elastic potential energy of the spring is \(0.64 \text{J}\)
calculate the decrease in gravitational potential energy of the block of weight \(2.5 \text{N}\)
decrease in potential energy =   .........  J
For the change in length of the spring from \(0.40 \text{m}\) to \(0.72 \text{m}\):
the kinetic energy of the block
kinetic energy =   .........  J
the speed of the block
Use the information in (a)(i) and your answer in (a)(ii) to determine, for the instant when the length of the spring is \(0.72 \text{m}\):
The variation with extension \(x\) of the force \(F\) acting on a spring is shown in Fig. 3.1
The spring of unstretched length \(0.40 \text{m}\) has one end attached to a fixed point, as shown in Fig. 3.2
Fig. 3.3

A block of weight \(2.5 \text{N}\) is then attached to the spring. The block is then released and begins to move downwards. At one instant, as the block is continuing to move downwards, the spring has a length of \(0.72 \text{m}\), as shown in Fig. 3.3
Assume that the air resistance and the mass of the spring are both negligible
Show that the mass of the oil drop is \(6.8 \times 10^{- 15} \text{kg}\)
The oil drop is charged. Explain why it is impossible for the magnitude of the charge to be \(8.0 \times 10^{- 20} \text{C}\)
A spherical oil drop has a radius of \(1.2 \times 10^{- 6} \text{m}\). The density of the oil is \(940 \text{kg} \text{m}^{- 3}\)
Calculate the potential difference \(V\) between the plates
Explain how the motion of the oil drop shows that it is in equilibrium
Determine the charge on the oil drop
charge =   .........  C
sign of charge
The charged oil drop in **(a)** is in a vacuum between two horizontal metal plates, as illustrated in Fig. 4.1
The plates are separated by a distance of \(8.0 \text{mm}\). The electric field between the plates is uniform and has a field strength of \(2.1 \times 10^{5} \text{V} \text{m}^{-1}\)
The oil drop moves vertically downwards with a constant speed
Explain why the oil drop accelerates downwards
Describe the change to the pattern of the field lines (lines of force) representing the uniform electric field as the potential difference decreases
The magnitude of the potential difference between the plates in (b) is decreased
force X
force Y

Two types of force, X and Y, can act on an oil drop when it is in air, but cannot act on an oil drop when it is in a vacuum. Force X can act on an oil drop when it is stationary or when it is moving. Force Y can only act on an oil drop when it is moving

1. the distance moved by a wavefront in time \(t\)
distance =
2. time \(t\)
time \(t =\)
Use your answers in (i) to deduce the equation relating the speed \(v\) of the sound wave to \(f\) and \(\lambda\)
A loudspeaker oscillates with frequency \(f\) to produce sound waves of wavelength \(\lambda\). The loudspeaker makes \(N\) oscillations in time \(t\)
The waveform of a sound wave is displayed on the screen of a cathode-ray oscilloscope (c.r.o.), as shown in Fig. 5.1
The time-base setting is \(0.20 \text{ms} \text{cm}^{-1}\)
Determine the frequency of the sound wave
Explain what is meant by coherent waves
State the phase difference between the two waves arriving at the position of minimum loudness Q that is closest to point X
phase difference =   .........
Determine the distance \(\mathsf{S}_1\mathsf{Y}\)
distance =   .........  m
Two sources \(\mathsf{S}_1\) and \(\mathsf{S}_2\) of sound waves are positioned as shown in Fig. 5.2

The sources emit coherent sound waves of wavelength \(0.85\mathrm{m}.\) A sound detector is moved parallel to the line \(\mathsf{S}_1\mathsf{S}_2\) from a point X to a point Y. Alternate positions of maximum loudness L and minimum loudness Q are detected, as illustrated in Fig. 5.2
Distance \(\mathsf{S}_1\mathsf{X}\) is equal to distance \(\mathsf{S}_2\mathsf{X}\). Distance \(\mathsf{S}_2\mathsf{Y}\) is \(7.40\mathrm{m}\)
Explain, in terms of energy, why \(V\) is less than \(E\)
State an equation relating \(E, I, r\) and \(V.\)
Use Fig. 6.2 to:
explain how it may be deduced that the e.m.f. of the battery is 2.8 V
calculate the internal resistance \(r\)
The resistance \(R\) of the variable resistor is varied. The variation with \(I\) of \(V\) is shown in Fig. 6.2
calculate resistance \(R\)
calculate the number of conduction electrons moving through the battery in a time of 1.0 s
determine the time taken for the energy in the battery to become equal to \(1.6 \text{kJ}\)
(Assume that the e.m.f. of the battery and the current in the battery remain constant.)
time taken =   .........  s
The battery stores \(9.2 \text{kJ}\) of energy. The variable resistor is adjusted so that \(V = 2.1 \text{V}\). Use Fig. 6.2 to:
A battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(E\) and internal resistance \(r\) is connected to a variable resistor of resistance \(R\), as shown in Fig. 6.1
The current in the circuit is \(I\) and the potential difference across the variable resistor is \(V.\)
One of the results of the \(\alpha\) -particle scattering experiment is that a very small minority of the \(\alpha\) -particles are scattered through angles greater than \(90^{\circ}\)
State what may be inferred about the structure of the atom from this result
State the charge, in terms of \(e,\) of the strange (s) quark
The other two quarks in the hadron have the same charge as each other
By considering charge, determine a possible type (flavour) of the other two quarks. Explain your working
A hadron has an overall charge of \(+e,\) where \(e\) is the elementary charge. The hadron contains three quarks. One of the quarks is a strange (s) quark
